Composed by Dharma Master Fazang of Xisi Temple in the Wei State
Therefore, the precept against stinginess is the first chapter, the precept against stinginess is the eighth
The first intention of the precept is as follows.
Because giving is the head of the myriad practices.
Because it includes the six perfections.
It is the abandonment of stinginess that becomes giving.
In brief, there are ten meanings.
As the Ten Practices Chapter of the Flower Ornament Sutra says,
This bodhisattva is a great donor.
He is able to let go of and abandon all that he has.
He gives equally to all sentient beings with an impartial mind.
After giving, he has no regrets.
He does not expect any rewards.ğŸ”½He does not seek fame.
He does not seek to be reborn in a superior place.
He does not seek material gain.
As for the ten,
First, he only wishes to save and protect all sentient beings.
Second, he wishes to embrace all sentient beings.
Third, he wishes to benefit all sentient beings.
Fourth, he wishes to learn the fundamental practices of all Buddhas.
Fifth, he wishes to correctly contemplate and remember the fundamental practices of the Buddhas.
Sixth, to purify the fundamental practices of all Buddhas.
Seventh, to uphold the fundamental practices of all Buddhas.
Eighth, to manifest the fundamental practices of all Buddhas.
Ninth, to extensively explain the fundamental practices of all Buddhas.
Tenth, to enable all sentient beings to leave suffering and attain the bliss of nirvana.
These are the ten.
Based on this, one should know that there is no practice of non-giving for bodhisattvas.
Second, explaining the names.
Being stingy with wealth and the Dharma, not fulfilling requests, is called intentional stinginess.
The precepts prevent this fault.
The name is established based on the master.
Third, the sequence.
Previously, praising and defaming oneself and others in order to seek fame and profit.
Looking forward to the time of pursuing wealth that has not yet been obtained.
Now, in terms of what has been obtained, being stingy and not letting go of wealth that belongs to oneself.
The time of hoarding is excessive.
The previous is coarse, this is subtle.
Because of the sequence of meaning, it comes.
Fourth, the conditions for committing the offense.
There are four places where one commits an offense in this precept.
First, being stingy oneself.
Second, teaching others.
Third, rejoicing.
Fourth, praising stinginess.
Now, I will discuss the conditions for self-fulfillment.
The other three are to be judged accordingly.
Self-fulfillment consists of six conditions.
First, one has wealth and Dharma.
Second, the beggar is present.
Third, one has the two thoughts mentioned above.
Fourth, one gives rise to a stingy and evil mind.
Fifth, one directly goes against the conditions.
Sixth, the other person returns empty-handed.
As for the meaning of incomplete conditions,
there are three meanings in omitting the first condition.
First, if one does not have even a needle or a blade of grass to give to them,
one should comfort the beggar with kind words and a sincere heart, shedding tears.
One should think like this:
I am now of little merit and cannot fulfill the wishes of sentient beings.
This is my fault.
I will diligently cultivate and practice so that my wishes will be fulfilled. Then one should be diligent and brave as one says.
This is called not committing an offense.
Second, if one is arrogant because one has no possessions and does not apologize but has no remorse,
one should incur a minor offense.
Third, if the beggar does not believe that one has nothing and repeatedly presses for it,
and then gives rise to a hateful mind, one immediately commits a grave offense.
If one then gives rise to anger, one immediately commits the later offense of anger.
The same applies to the giving of the Dharma.
Next, there are four meanings for lacking the second condition.
First, if there is no begging, there is no offense.
Second, if one has one's own wealth, etc.,
and sees a greedy suffering person who is unable to beg or who is too embarrassed to beg,
but does not give, one still commits an offense.
Third, if one has one's own wealth,
and sees a fellow practitioner lacking in clothing and food, neglecting to cultivate the correct practice,
and that person does not seek it out for themselves, not giving to them is an offense.
Fourth, if one has previously accumulated much wealth,
even if there is no one begging, not giving it away due to not letting go of the field of merit,
one still commits a preparatory offense in these latter three cases.
This is because one does not directly commit a grave offense.
There are two for lacking the third condition.
First, each of the above two cases has two distinctions of conception and doubt.
Conception is not an offense.
Doubt is a preparatory offense.
All can be understood by analogy.
There are two cases of lacking the fourth condition.
If one tames them with a compassionate mind, there is no offense.
If one commits an offense with a neutral mind, the expedient means can be known.
Next, there are four cases of lacking the fifth condition.
The first is committing a grave offense by either agreeing to give or not giving.
The second is giving much or little.
The third is giving inferior when agreeing to give superior.
The fourth is giving later in violation of the proper time.
The latter three are all expedient means.
Next, there are two cases of lacking the sixth condition.
The first is no offense if one does not return empty-handed.
The second is committing an expedient means if one returns empty-handed but the intention is not yet cut off.
The sixth is the heaviness and lightness, which has five aspects.
First, regarding objects.
Second, regarding fields.
Third, regarding harm.
Fourth, regarding the mind.
Fifth, combining the explanations.
First, regarding wealth, Dharma, and fearlessness.
There are three kinds of giving wealth:
outer, inner, and both.
Regarding outer wealth, in general there are ten kinds.
First, food, etc.
Second, medicine, etc.
Third, clothing, etc.
Fourth, wealth, etc.
Fifth, animals, etc.
Sixth, slaves.
Seventh, fame.
Eighth, kingship.
Ninth, wives and concubines.
Tenth, sons and daughters.
All the former are not to be given and should be considered serious.
The latter are not to be given and should be considered light.
Second, there are five in the inner body.
First, temporarily requesting to be driven and used.
Second, taking hair, nails, etc.
Third, taking as a slave.
Fourth, taking blood and marrow from the limbs.
Fifth, taking the whole body and life.ğŸ”½The former are not to be given and are all serious.
The latter are not to be given and are all light.
Second, there are three in the Dharma giving.
First, worldly Dharma.
Second, the Dharma of the two vehicles.
Third, the Dharma of the bodhisattva path.
Third, there are three in the giving of fearlessness.
First, abandoning evil.
Second, abandoning suffering.
Third, saving lives.
The above two levels are all light if not given beforehand.
It should be known that if not given later, it is serious.
Second, there are four in terms of the field.
First, the field of kindness, referring to parents, teachers, and superiors, etc.
Second, the field of virtue refers to the Three Jewels and so forth.
Third, the field of compassion refers to hungry and impoverished sentient beings and so forth.
Fourth, the field of suffering refers to sentient beings in distress and so forth.
All the former are not as serious as the latter.
The latter should not be as light as the former.
Third, in terms of harm,
there are two kinds for each of the above four objects.
One is by not providing relief, causing them to die.
The second is causing great suffering and distress even if their lives are not ended.
All have the former being more serious than the latter, which should be known.
Fourth, in terms of the mind, there are also single and combined forms of the three poisons.
Understand it according to the above.
Moreover, stinginess has three grades.
Like the elder LÃ¼zhi and so forth, it is the most serious.
The middle and lower grades can be known.
Fifth, in terms of combining,ğŸ”½either giving rise to superior stinginess towards inferior objects, or towards superior objects, it is the most serious.
Or giving rise to inferior stinginess towards inferior objects, it should be lighter.
The other phrases should be understood accordingly.
Seventh, in terms of obtaining retribution, ten kinds are briefly explained.
One will be born in the realm of hungry ghosts.
Like MaudgalyÄyana's mother and others.
Second, one may experience suffering in other realms.
Like a mange-ridden jackal.
Not even a single hair to cover one's body, and so on.
Third, one will experience the suffering of poverty in the human realm.
Fourth, one will deplete and diminish one's past wholesome roots.
Fifth, one will lose the bodhisattva's perfection of generosity.
Sixth, due to stinginess with the Dharma, one will always be born foolish and poor.
The Sutra of Good Increase says:
If one is stingy with wealth, the Dharma, and food,
one should know that this person will receive the retribution of foolish poverty for immeasurable lifetimes.
Seventh, due to concealing the Dharma, one will always be blind.
Eighth, due to not giving fearlessness, one will always be fearful and never have temporary peace.
Ninth, one will always be taken advantage of by one's enemies.
Tenth, one will cause the three types of generosity and the six perfections to be incomplete.
The rest is explained elsewhere.
The eighth, the practitioner's antidotes, are briefly shown to be ten kinds.
First, contemplate that one's own body and wealth are all impermanent and subject to decay.
Once they are lost, it is not possible to keep them.
Therefore, stinginess and hoarding are of no benefit.
Second, moreover, these are all shared by the king, thieves, water, fire, and bad children.
Since they have not yet invaded, one should quickly give them away and place them in a secure storehouse to belong to oneself forever.
Third, if one is stingy and does not give, one plants the karma of poverty in life after life, which follows one's own body.
Fourth, moreover, because I did not cultivate giving in my previous lives, I now have stinginess and cannot give.
If I do not make an effort to give now,
this habit will not be broken but will increase and obstruct great giving. Therefore,
I should now make an effort to go against stinginess and practice giving.
Fifth, moreover, if one is poor and lacks means to survive,
and is stingy and does not give, one should contemplate:
Poverty is an obstacle to giving.
In order to break through this obstacle,
one should endure hardship and make an effort to practice giving.
I have previously experienced various sufferings such as hunger and thirst due to my past karma.
I was unable to benefit even a single sentient being.
Now, by practicing generosity, I can benefit others.
Even if I experience various sufferings up to the point of losing my life, I will never let a beggar return empty-handed.
How much less would I have remaining vegetables and other things to sustain my life?
Therefore, I should endure this poverty and practice generosity.
Sixth, if one is unable to give up one's body, life, or cherished possessions, one should contemplate:
When I generated the great bodhi mind in the presence of the Great Teacher of the Three Realms,
I had already given up everything internal and external.
How can I now go against my original vow and disappoint sentient beings?
Seventh, it would cause me to commit a pÄrÄjika offense as a bodhisattva.
I would then be deceiving the buddhas of the ten directions.
This is utterly unacceptable.
Eighth, I now abandon this impermanent, foul-smelling body.
Now I shall attain the pure Dharma body, the solid Dharma.
Since this benefits me,
if I do not practice giving, I will lose great benefits.
9. This body and wealth are false things.
I will not even give up fulfilling the wishes of sentient beings.
How can I use unsurpassed enlightenment to benefit sentient beings?
10. I should contemplate the emptiness of all dharmas, without self or possessions.
Yet now, I am stingy and do not give up this false body and wealth.
How can I realize and enter the equal nature of dharmas?
Contemplating these ten kinds of antidotes,
there is nothing that cannot be given up in terms of stinginess.
As fully explained in the Flower Ornament Sutra, Treatise on the Perfection of Wisdom, and Compendium of the Great Vehicle, etc.
Ninth, regarding the scope,
according to the 39th chapter of the Compendium of the Great Vehicle,
there are generally thirty kinds of non-giving that are not offenses.
1. If one knows that various internal and external things given to sentient beings only bring them happiness, or neither happiness nor benefit,
one should not give them.
2. If someone comes seeking to be a companion,
If one wishes to harm others through improper means,
one should not give one's body to them.
Third, if a bodhisattva's intention to practice giving is pure,
and he sees immeasurable matters of benefiting sentient beings right in front of him,
even if someone comes to request his own limbs and joints,
he should not give them.
Fourth, if the demons are filled with the intention to harm,
and they come to request his limbs and joints right in front of him,
he should not give them.
Because he thinks that they will incur grave offenses and do harm in return.
Fifth, if there are sentient beings who are insane and confused,
and they come to request the bodhisattva's limbs and joints,
he should not give them.
Sixth, if there are sentient beings who either want to harm themselves or harm others,
and they come to request poison, fire, knives, alcohol, and other such things,
he should not give them.
Seventh, one should not give away the belongings of others as if they were one's own.
Eighth, one should not practice giving by acting as a matchmaker and giving away the wives and concubines of others.
Ninth, do not give food or drink that contains insects.
Tenth, if sentient beings come seeking various things that can lead to play and amusement, or things that can lead to meaninglessness,
one should not give them.
Because it would cause them to engage in much arrogance and evil conduct.
After the body perishes, they will fall into the evil destinies.
Eleventh, never give people things for hunting and killing.
Twelfth, if there are sentient beings who are about to kill,
never give them things to kill with.
Thirteenth, if someone comes seeking nets, traps, and snares,
to harm sentient beings or to learn how to do so,
all should not be given to them.
Fourteenth, if an enemy comes seeking revenge,
to scold, bind, kill, steal wealth, or punish,
never give them what they seek.
To put it simply,
all instruments of oppression, harm, and play for sentient beings should not be given.
Fifteenth, if a sick person comes seeking food and drink that is not in moderation or not suitable,
it should also not be given.
Sixteenth, if there are sentient beings who have eaten until full and whose nature is prone to greed and indulgence,
they frequently come seeking delicious food and drink,
and they are also not given.
Seventeenth, if there are those who come seeking parents, teachers, and elders,
they are definitely not given.
Eighteenth, moreover, bodhisattvas, regarding their own wives, children, slaves, servants, relatives, and family members,
if they have not first enlightened and delighted them with correct speech,
they will never force them to suffer in order to give to those who come seeking.
Nineteenth, although they have first enlightened and delighted them with correct speech, causing them to give rise to a mind of joy and desire,

Twentieth, if there are those who greatly afflict sentient beings and delight in engaging in various violent and evil activities,

If those evil people are already ruling a kingdom,
even if the bodhisattvas have the power, they should still depose them,

Twenty-first, moreover, bodhisattvas never encroach upon or steal the wealth of their parents, wives, children, slaves, servants, attendants, relatives, or associates, and use it for giving.
Twenty-second, they also do not oppress their parents, wives, children, slaves, servants, or relatives and associates, and give the wealth they have obtained to those who come seeking.
Twenty-third, they do not use non-dharma or violence.
They also do not harm others through coercion while practicing giving.
Twenty-fourth, moreover, if bodhisattvas have left the household life in the holy teachings of the buddhas,

Twenty-fifth, moreover, bodhisattvas never give unsuitable things to those who come seeking.
That is to say, they do not give leftover food and drink, etc. to those who have left the household life.
Or those that are mixed with or tainted by various impurities such as nasal mucus, saliva, vomit, pus, blood, or other unclean substances.

Moreover, bodhisattvas never orally transmit the correct teachings of non-Buddhists who seek faults.

Knowing those who are greedy by nature and wish to sell scriptures, etc.,

Knowing those who wish to keep them secret, they also do not give to them.

9. The Precept Against Anger, Part One, the Ninth Precept. The initial intention is summarized by ten points.
First, among delusions, none is heavier than this.
Second, it also forms karmic paths and causes for evil destinies.
Third, it burns up the roots of goodness from past lives.
Fourth, it can bind great enmity for many eons, difficult to untie.
Fifth, because of this, it can harm all sentient beings.
Sixth, it can even commit the crime of immediate retribution.
Seventh, it can obstruct the bodhisattva's perfection of patience.
Eighth, it harms the bodhisattvas' great compassion.
Ninth, it causes all sentient beings to be abandoned.
Tenth, it fully accomplishes hundreds of thousands of hindrances.
The Huayan Sutra extensively quotes.
It also says:
I do not see a single evil dharma that surpasses a bodhisattva's single angry thought.
Since the harm is so great, it must be prohibited.
Second, explaining the name.
It means to give rise to a harmful mind towards an opposing object.
The precepts prevent this loss and are named accordingly.
The third is the sequence.
Because stinginess and greed come before anger, it comes next.
The fourth is the requisite conditions.
First, there is an opposing object.
Second, one gives rise to the thought of that.
Third, one does not restrain the mind.
Fourth, if one gives rise to anger, one then violates.
This is based on the mind.
If one includes body and speech, one adds beating and scolding.
If one takes the five conditions, one violates.
If one takes it to the extreme, one adds the other person coming to apologize, but one is still angry and does not understand.
If one takes the six conditions, one then violates.
The fifth is the incomplete conditions.
There are three for the incomplete first condition.
Namely, the difference in sentient beings.
If there is a difference in insentient things.
If there is a difference in sentient and insentient things.
If based on the mind, both are heavy.
Directly facing the body and speech, there is lightness.
Next, there are three for the incomplete second condition.
Namely, the difference in original delusion, thought, and doubt.
Based on the mind, both are heavy.
The body and speech have lightness that can be known.
There are two for the incomplete third condition.
The first is when one frequently cultivates and attends to forgetfulness, using light skillful means.
The second is when one does not cultivate and attend, using heavy skillful means.
Next, there are three when lacking the fourth condition.
That is, if one arouses a lesser mind of anger, one immediately regrets it, using light skillful means.
Second, if one arouses lesser anger but does not regret it, it is heavy skillful means.
Third, if one arouses middling anger and immediately regrets it, it is heavy skillful means.
The rest can be understood as falling into the heavy category.
If we consider body and speech,
lacking the heavy skillful means of beating and scolding,
the opposite becomes heavy.
If we consider the utmost,
further repentance by others and one's own regret constitute heavy skillful means.
The opposite becomes heavy.
Sixth, as for the light and heavy,
it is roughly distinguished in five categories.ğŸ”½First, in terms of the object.
Second, in terms of the cause and circumstances.
Third, in terms of the characteristics of the afflictions.
Fourth, in terms of the extent of harm.
Fifth, combining to distinguish.
In the beginning, there are roughly ten kinds of objects of anger.
First, the sages; second,
teachers;
third, parents; fourth,
the transmitter of the Dharma;
The five are the five classes of Buddhist disciples.
The six are laypeople.
The seven are one's own male and female disciples.
The eight are male and female servants.
The nine are animals.
The ten are non-sentient beings.
From the perspective of precepts, all are equally grave.
From the perspective of karmic paths, the former are graver and the latter are lighter.
Second, regarding the causes, in brief, anger arises due to ten causes.
First, contradicting one's own understanding.
Second, contradicting one's own desires.
Third, encroaching on one's fame and profit.
Fourth, harming one's relatives.
Fifth, unjustly being scolded.
Sixth, unjustly being beaten or bound.
Seventh, having one's limbs cut off.
Eighth, being about to have one's life taken.
Ninth, harming one's parents.
Tenth, destroying the Three Jewels.
Anger arises due to these ten causes.
All are graver in the former and lighter in the latter.
Third, regarding the characteristics of delusions, ten kinds are also distinguished.
First, a thought arises and the angry face has no different color.
Second, the complexion changes.
Third, the whole body trembles.
Fourth, one may beat or scold.
Fifth, one regrets immediately after committing the offense.
Sixth, one regrets after a night has passed.
Seventh, one does not let go for a long time.
Eighth, the other person apologizes briefly and one immediately forgives.
Ninth, the other person seeks forgiveness for a long time before one forgives.
Tenth, one does not forgive even after seeking forgiveness for a long time.
All should be known as progressively lighter and heavier.
Fourth, in terms of harm, ten kinds are also briefly shown.
First, because of anger, one causes others to abandon the Buddha's teachings.
Second, one utters more evil scolding.
Third, one beats, binds, or restrains others.
Fourth, one damages others' property.
Fifth, one dismembers others.
Sixth, one severs others' life roots.
Seventh, one harms one's own relatives.
Eighth, one permanently abandons the Three Jewels.
Ninth, one burns temples and harms monks.
Tenth, one commits various heinous crimes.
All should be known as progressively lighter and heavier.
Fifth, in the combined explanation, ten levels are also shown.
That is, among the first four, the most serious is to give rise to grave anger and cause great harm to a venerable object due to a minor matter.
The rest should be combined in sequence.
And there are also light and heavy [offenses] for those that are not in sequence, etc.
One can understand this by analogy.
Seventh, as for the karmic retribution, ten kinds are briefly shown.
First, ten offenses are obtained due to anger.
As the Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom says.
Second, due to anger, one enters the eight great hells.
As the first fascicle of the Sutra on Good Admonitions says.
Third, one also falls into the realms of hungry ghosts and animals.
The Flower Ornament Sutra says:
The greatest offense of anger is the cause for the hells.
The middling is rebirth as an animal.
The lesser is rebirth as a hungry ghost.
The above are the karmic fruits.
Fourth, as for the equal flow fruit,
the sutra says:
If one is reborn among humans, one obtains two kinds of karmic retribution.
First, one is always sought out by others for their shortcomings.
Second, one is always harmed by others.
Fifth, as for the dominant fruit, in terms of the supported environment,
the Abhidharma-samuccaya-vyÄkhyÄ says that due to anger, the taste of the fruit becomes bitter.
Sixth, one's body is always ugly and people do not like to see it.
Seventh, one loses the bliss of meditation in the upper realms.
Eighth, it contradicts the liberation of the two vehicles.
Ninth, it harms the two benefits of the bodhisattvas.
Tenth, it loses the five stages of the bodhisattvas.
It should be known.
The eighth is the practitioner of cultivation.
Briefly discerning ten kinds of antidotes to prevent anger from arising.
First, contemplation.
All sentient beings from beginningless time have never not been my parents, relatives, close family members, preceptors, elders, and so forth.
Therefore, one should only give rise to a compassionate mind and a filial mind.
How can one become angry and strike or scold?
Second, contemplation of impermanence.
The Yoga says:
Those sentient beings, whether born or grown, are all impermanent and subject to death.
The ultimate requital of resentment is to end their lives.
The lives of all sentient beings are cut off moment by moment.
Why would the wise wish to cut them off again?
In this way, sentient beings are impermanent and subject to birth and death.
The wise should not give rise to a defiled mind.
How much less so would I use my hands, clods of earth, or sticks to harm them?
How much less so would I completely cut off their lives?
Therefore, I can endure all enmity and harm.
Third, contemplating suffering.
The Yoga SÅ«tra says:
Moreover, the bodies of self and others are all essentially painful.
Because they are ignorant, they increase suffering on top of the essentially painful body.
Since I have knowledge,
how can I increase suffering on top of their essentially painful bodies?
Moreover, those sentient beings who are greatly prosperous are still constantly followed by the three kinds of suffering,
how much more so those who are in decline.
I should now diligently apply skillful means to enable them to be free from suffering,
I should not increase their suffering.
